HBV is a partially double-stranded DNA virus that is transmitted via the parenteral route, and can cause acute or chronic infection. The risk of chronicity is dependent mainly on the age of the host at the time of infection, as the vast majority of infants (>90%) and only <5% of adults develop chronic HBV infection after exposure. Distinguishing between acute, chronic, past (resolved), and occult infection lies in HBV serological markers and measurement of serum HBV-DNA ( Table 1 and Figure 1).
